_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Targa Badlands LLC -  Little Missouri Gas Plant

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Targa Resources is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contract workers, our neighbors, the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is strongly supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility.  Targa Resources implements both administrative and engineering controls to reasonably minimize the risk of an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance.  The Little Missouri Gas Plant does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However, if an uncontrolled release does occur, the personnel supporting the site in cooperation with local agencies are trained to respond, minimize and eliminate any exposure that would occur to protect employees and the surrounding area.



Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Little Missouri Gas Plant is located near Watford City, North Dakota and is a natural gas processing plant which receives raw natural casing gas from oil well production.  Natural gas liquids (NGLs) are extracted from the raw gas and stored on site.  The extracted NGLs include methane, ethane, propane, butane and a pentane natural gasoline mixture that is delivered to market via transportation vehicles and/or pipeline.  There is also a heavier flammable mixture (condensate) which is produced and sent out via transportation vehicles and/or pipeline. The gas remaining after the liquids extraction it routed to a natural gas pipeline for commercial sale.  There is also refrigerant propane at the site.  There are no listed toxic substances which exceed their respective threshold quantities stored at this facility.



Facility Location and Driving Directions

T

he Little Missouri Gas Plant's location address is 1939 125th Ave NW, Watford City, ND 58854.  Driving directions have been included for clarification of facility location.  The facility can be found by traveling State Highway 85 south for 5.6 miles from Watford City, North Dakota until it intersects with County Road 37.  Travel 0.5 miles east on County Road 37 to the intersection with 125th Avenue NW.  From intersection of County Road 37 and 125th Avenue NW, travel south on 125th Avenue NW for 1.8 miles to the Little Missouri facility.



Hazard Assessment - Worst Case Scenario

The Worst Case Scenario for this facility is a release of a flammable mixture that would result as a failure of a hydrocarbon vessel releasing the entire contents instantaneously to the atmosphere having an offsite impact.  EPA's RMP*Comp was used to calculate a scenario where the entire contents of the largest facility vessel was considered for a vapor cloud explosion release.  This type of scenario is unlikely to occur.  In addition, qualified individuals operate the subject processes.  The equipment is inspected and maintained according to a preventative maintenance schedule further reducing the likelihood of this release occurring.





General Accident Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the accidental release prevention program in place at the Little Missouri Gas Plant.  The Little Missouri Gas Plant has been classified as a Program 3 facility because of the close proximity to a nearby commercial facility.  The facility is not only regulated by the EPA's Risk Management Program but also the OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  This summary addresses many of the OSHA PSM elements. 



Employee Participation 

Targa Resources encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling process safety information to participation as a member

of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's PSM and accidental release prevention programs.  In addition, facility has a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues including plant safety meetings and safety training to promote both process and personal safety.



Process Safety Information

Targa Resources keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Up-to-date process safety information is maintained on a going basis.  The reference documents are readily available at the plant location.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS).  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within safe operating limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



The gas plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes material of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.  This information, in combination with trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features integral to the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Targa Resources systematically examines the Little Missouri Gas Plant facility processes to identify any potential hazards and ensures that adequate controls are in place to m

anage these hazards. 



The Little Missouri Gas Plant primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  OSHA and the EPA recognize the analysis as an approved method for conducting PHAs.  Plant PHAs are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering and safety expertise.  The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



The PHA team findings are forwarded to company's local and corporate management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in responses to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



Targa Resources periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results to ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly over time from the original design and safety features.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  Any team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings are documented and retained.



Operating Procedures

The Little Missouri Gas Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as:



1.    Unit startup

2.    Normal operations

3

.    Temporary operations

4.    Emergency shutdown

5.    Normal shutdown

6.    Initial startup of a new process



These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.  



Training

An established comprehensive training program has been developed and implemented by Targa Resources.  All employees are trained in an overview of the process as well as in appropriate safe work practices.  In addition to training required of all employees, personnel having specific responsibilities under the operating and maintenance procedures are aptly trained in those procedures.



Contractors

Targa Resources uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the gas plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:



1.    Perform their work in a safe manner

2.    Have the appropriate knowledge and skills

3.    Are aware of the hazards in their workplace

4.    Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency

5.    Understand and follow site safety rules

6.    Inform gas plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work



This is accomplished by providing contractors with:

1.    Process Overview

2.    Information about safety and health hazards

3.    Emergency response plan requirements

4.    Safe work practices prior to their beginning work

5.    Site safety comprehension test



Targa Resources evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

T

arga Resources conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



Mechanical Integrity

Targa Resources has established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pump and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include:



1.    Maintenance and operational personnel training

2.    Developing written procedures

3.    Performing inspections and tests

4.    Correcting identified deficiencies

5.    Applying quality assurance measures



The combination of these activities forms a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.



Safe Work Practices

Safe work practices have been developed to ensure safe operations that are consistent with industry practice and meet regulatory requirements.  Safe work practices include site control, lockout/tagout, line breaking, confined space entry and hot work to ensure the safety and well being of employees and the surrounding area.



Management of Change (MOC)

Targa Resources has developed a MOC program to ensure that all permanent and temporary changes to flammable or hazardous processes maintain or enhance the safety, environmental, mechanical and technical integrity of the intended design.  The primary intent of the

MOC program is to preclude the occurrence of catastrophic releases that could occur through the improper control of changes.



The MOC program applies to all permanent and temporary changes involving any chemicals, procedures, process equipment, processing rates, technology, control systems, monitoring systems and safety systems associated with flammable or hazardous processes.  The MOC program requires that changes be documented, authorized by appropriate facility personnel, and that the changes are adequately conducted to prevent any type of release.  The MOC program also ensures that changes are communicated to affected personnel and that training has been conducted as necessary.



Incident Investigation

Targa Resources promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.



Compliance Audits

Targa Resources periodically conducts an audit of the Little Missouri Gas Plant to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented and functioning properly.  Compliance audits are scheduled at least every 3

years.  Audit findings are forwarded to the plant management team for resolution.  The management team initiates any corrective actions taken in response to the audit and tracks them until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



5 Year Accident History

The Little Missouri Gas Plant has not had any RMP-reportable releases in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program

This facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated with the local fire department for response to large accidental releases. As a non-responding facility, the RMP emergency response program and emergency response plan requirements (40 CFR 68.95) are not applicable at this facility. However, the facility does maintain an emergency response plan that serves as guidance for facility employees to notify first responders, secure critical operations before evacuation, evacuate the facility and account for personnel, among other items. Facility personnel are trained in procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in response to small accidental releases.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Targa Resources personnel are continually developing new ways to improve the safety of its equipment and operations.  This is done through training which is considered a vital part of any safety program.  Training is conducted according to a schedule so employees and contractors are given the most up-to-date information available.  All new and modified equipment is designed with appropriate safety controls and devices.



Management System

The Area Manager has overall responsibility for development, implementation and integration of the risk management program at this facility. Specific responsibilities are summarized in the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.
